raw_text:
Paraguay novel wins US book prize
 
 A novel set in 19th century Paraguay has won the $10,000 (£5,390) fiction prize at the US National Book Awards.
 
 Lily Tuck's The News From Paraguay is a fictionalised tale about Paraguayan leader Francisco Solano Lopez and his Irish mistress. But the annual awards, which were presented in New York on Wednesday, were not without controversy. Children's author Judy Blume, who was given an honourary medal, used the ceremony to speak out over censorship.
 
 Sales of Blume's books have exceeded 75 million, but her work - which features frank narratives about families, religion and sexuality - is closely watched by the censors. Blume said: "The urge to ban is contagious. It spreads like wildfire from community to community. Please speak out. Censors hate publicity." Her medal marks the second year in a row the honourary prize went to someone as notable for popular success as literary greatness. Last year's honorary winner, Stephen King, accused the industry during the 2003 ceremony of snobbery against popular writers. But his argument that the award should help sell books instead of honouring excellence is not shared by everyone.
 
 This year's fiction panel overlooked high-profile works such as Philip Roth's The Plot Against America and instead chose five little-known books, all by New York-based women. One fiction judge, Stewart O'Nan, carried around a note written on a napkin that said: "I would hope that our caring more for the quality of a work than its sales figures make us a friend of books, not an enemy." The National Book Awards non-fiction prize was awarded to Kevin Boyle's for Arc of Justice, which focuses on a black family's fight to live in a white Detroit neighbourhood in the 1920s. The award had created a lot of interest this year after the surprise inclusion of the of the 9-11 Commission Report looking into the events of the 11 September terrorist attacks on the US. Pete Hautman won the young people's literature prize for his novel Godless. The winner in the poetry category was Jean Valentine for Door in the Mountain: New and Collected Poems, 1965-2003.
llama3.2:1b: Paraguay novel wins $10,000 book prize at US National Book Awards; controversy over censorship during ceremony by children's author Judy Blume is noted. Sales of Blume's books exceed 75 million, but her work is closely watched by censors. Her medal marks the second year in a row for someone notable for popular success. This year's fiction panel chose lesser-known books by New York-based women over high-profile works like Roth and King.
llama3.2:3b: A Paraguayan novel has won the $10,000 fiction prize at the US National Book Awards, while children's author Judy Blume received an honorary medal amidst controversy over censorship. The awards ceremony saw notable works like Philip Roth's "The Plot Against America" overlooked in favor of lesser-known books by women writers.

Judy Blume received an honorary medal, using it to speak out about censorship concerns. The awards ceremony also saw the non-fiction prize go to Kevin Boyle for his book "Arc of Justice."
qwen2.5:0.5b: A novel set in Paraguay has been accepted for its first time by the US National Book Awards. It is written by Lily Tuck and tells a fictionalized story about Paraguayan leader Francisco Solano Lopez and his Irish mistress. The book's sales have exceeded 75 million, but Blume, who received an honorary medal, was criticized for using the ceremony to speak out over censorship. This year's fiction panel overlooked high-profile works such as Philip Roth's The Plot Against America and instead chose five little-known books from New York-based women authors.

qwen2.5:3b: A novel about Paraguayan leader Francisco Solano López set in the 19th century won the US National Book Awards fiction prize. Judy Blume, honored with an honorary medal, criticized censorship and urged public support against it. This year's panel chose five little-known books instead of high-profile works like Philip Roth's, citing quality over sales figures. Kevin Boyle's "Arc of Justice" won non-fiction, while Pete Hautman's "Godless" took young people’s literature prize. Jean Valentine's collection of poetry was the winner in the poetry category.
opencoder:1.5b:
Paraguay novel wins US book prize.

A novel set in the 19th century Paraguay has won the $10,000 (£5,390) fiction prize at the US National Book Awards. This year, a book by a renowned author, Lily Tuck, features a story about Paraguayan leader Francisco Solano Lopez and his Irish mistress, and it was an important event that shook up the country's culture.
The annual awards were not without controversy. The author of Blume's books, Judy Blume, gave an honourary medal in recognition of her work. She shared her enthusiasm for banning censorship, which spread rapidly from community to community. But critics criticized her use of the ceremony and its argument over popularity.

This year, the book of Stephen King was also invited to a non-fiction panel by the industry. The panel chose five little-known books written by New York-based women. One judge noted that the notes on the napkins were intended to provide insight into their appearance and purpose. The National Book Awards' non-fiction prize was won by a female director of film, Kevin Boyle's for Arc of Justice.
The award is said to have created a lot of interest this year as it allowed more people to read about the books, which has significantly influenced book industry dynamics in the last few decades.
Pete Hautman also won a literary prize for his novel Godless. The winner in the poetry category was Jean Valentine's collection of New and Collected Poems from 19th century to present.

I should ensure that each important point is included without getting bogged down in details. Also, since it's only plain text, I need to avoid any markdown or special formatting. The user emphasized not including explanations or reasoning, just a direct summary.

Then, touch on her honorific medal and the controversy surrounding it with Stephen King. Also, include the other awards mentioned, like for Arc of Justice, Pete Hautman's win, Jean Valentine's poetry prize, and Kevin Boyle's non-fiction.

I need to make sure all these points are covered succinctly without losing any critical information. I'll structure each main idea as a bullet point or a couple of sentences separated by commas in the summary.

The novel about Francisco Solano Lopez won $10,000 in the 2023 US National Book Awards. Judy Blume awarded her honorific medal for her book, speaking out against censorship during the ceremony. Her work features fictional narratives on families, religion, and sexuality, closely watched by censors. Her sold over 75 million books are receiving widespread critical attention. Last year's honorific was shared with Stephen King, but this year Blume faced controversy from other writers. The awards highlighted a vibrant industry with notable winners like Stewart O'Nan and Pete Hautman.
tinyllama:1.1b:
Paraguay novel wins US book prize

A novel set in 19th century Paraiguay has won the $10,000 fiction prize at the US National Book Awards. Liliana Tuccillo's The News From Paraiguay is a fictionalised tale about Paraquayan leader Francisco Solano López and his Irish mistress. However, the annual awards, which were presented in New York on Wednesday, have not been without controversy. Children's author Judy Blume used the ceremony to speak out against censorship, referring to her own work as "a frank narrative of families, religion and sexuality". The award went to one of five little-known books that were chosen over high-profile works such as Philip Roth's The Plot Against America. One judge, Stewart O'Naan, suggested that the awards aimed to honour excellence rather than popular success. Despite this, several notable works were not awarded a prize, including Philip Roth's The Plot Against America and Kevin Boyle's Arc of Justice.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In this year's US National Book Awards, Paraguay's Lily Tuck's The News from Paraguay won the $10,000 fiction prize. However, controversy surrounded the award as noted children's author Judy Blume used her honorary medal to speak out against censorship in literature. In addition, this year's fiction panel overlooked high-profile works such as Philip Roth's The Plot Against America and opted for five lesser-known books by New York-based women. Non-fiction award recipients include Kevin Boyle's Arc of Justice, focusing on a black family's fight to live in a white Detroit neighborhood in the 1920s, and Pete Hautman's Godless, which examines the events surrounding the US terrorist attacks on 9/11.
phi:2.7b: A Paraguayan historical fiction novel about a leader's Irish mistress has won the US National Book Awards' $10,000 fiction prize. Children's author Judy Blume speaks out over censorship of her work, which often features frank narratives about families, religion and sexuality. The panel for this year's fiction prize overlooked high-profile works in favour of five little-known books by New York-based women. The National Book Awards' non-fiction prize was awarded to Kevin Boyle's Arc of Justice, a book about a black family's fight to live in a white Detroit neighbourhood in the 1990s. Pete Hautman won the young people's literature prize for his novel Godless. Jean Valentine's Door in the Mountain: New and Collected Poems won the poetry category.
